page.title: 11St Peters Church
page.content: At the heart of every English village there is always a church. There existed a wooden Saxon church at Tempsford until 1010 when it was destroyed by the Danes. In 1129 a small stone built Norman church was constructed. The present day building was built in the late 14thC. The naves & arcades were repaired in oolite in the 17thC and still bear the original masons marks.The font the east windows and the rood screen stairs still remain from the 14thC work. Inside the church is a large oak chest (8") carved from a single tree which used to contain the parish records. In 1874 during restoration work to the church the chest was removed to a local barn where it suffered bad flood damage and many records were destroyed.
